On 9/20/05, John H. E. <johnemb@...> wrote:
>
> --- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> > Oops, sorry. I kept reading "CLDC" whenever you wrote "CDC". Reflection
> > is definitely an option then.
>
> OK, good :)
>
> > I still think that there is little point in testing on the device
> > itself. Or rather, that it makes little sense as long as you don't have
> a > set of tests on the emulator.
>
> Uhm... not sure I follow. I presume testing on the device itself would be
> better than no testing at all, e.g. in the event that you don't have a
> good enough emulator, or emulator tests.


My experience is that testing on an emulator should be the first priority
because it will catch a lot of bugs that will happen on *all* devices. Once
you have a comprehensive emulator test suite, you will probably see that
your code works fine on 90% of the devices and that 10% of them will require
additional debugging (on-device this time, since these bugs didn't show on
the emulator).

Most of the bugs that I see in JavaME applications are simple programming
errors, not device-specific errors, and they can therefore be exposed and
tested in an emulator. But maybe your experience differs?

--
Cedric


Anyway, if you are insterested in knowing whether or not your application
> will run ("correctly") on "some" J2ME device, it would also be better than
> nothing to run your tests in a J2ME JVM on a regular desktop machine or
> something like that, running for example linux or Windows (if the virtual
> machine supports one of those platforms). This might be a good alternative
> if you are not able to get hold of a suitable, full-featured emulator.
> Right?
